factoid: The people of the west moved eastwards to slay their fellow men.
Thousands of minute causes coordinated to produce the movement and war.
Reproaches for the nonobservance of the Continental System were causes.
The Duke of Oldenburg’s wrongs were causes.
Napoleon thought the movement of troops into Prussia was undertaken only to secure an armed peace.
Napoleon's love and habit of war coincided with the inclinations of his people.
Allurement by the grandeur of the preparations was a cause.
The expenditure on those preparations was a cause.
The need of obtaining advantages to compensate for that expenditure was a cause.
The intoxicating honors Napoleon received in Dresden were a cause.
Diplomatic negotiations were carried on with a sincere desire to attain peace, according to contemporaries.
Those negotiations only wounded the self-love of both sides.
Millions of other causes adapted themselves to the event that was happening or coincided with it.
An apple falls because of its attraction to the earth.
An apple falls because its stalk withers.
An apple falls because it is dried by the sun.
An apple falls because it grows heavier.
An apple falls because the wind shakes it.
An apple falls because the boy standing below wants to eat it.
Nothing is the cause of an apple falling.
The apple falling is the coincidence of conditions in which all vital organic and elemental events occur.
A botanist who attributes the apple falling to cellular tissue decay is equally right as a child who attributes it to wanting to eat it and praying for it.
A person who says Napoleon went to Moscow because he wanted to is equally right or wrong.
A person who says Napoleon perished because Alexander desired his destruction is equally right or wrong.
A person who says an undermined hill weighing a million tons fell because the last navvy struck it for the last time with his mattock is equally right or wrong.
In historic events, so-called great men are labels giving names to events.
Great men have only the smallest connection with the event itself.
Every act of great men, which appears to them an act of their own will, is involuntary in historical sense.
Every act of great men is related to the whole course of history and predestined from eternity.
On the twenty-ninth of May Napoleon left Dresden.
Napoleon had spent three weeks in Dresden surrounded by a court that included princes, dukes, kings, and an emperor.
Before leaving, Napoleon showed favor to the emperor, kings, and princes who had deserved it.
Napoleon reprimanded the kings and princes with whom he was dissatisfied.
Napoleon presented pearls and diamonds of his own to the Empress of Austria.
Napoleon had taken those pearls and diamonds from other kings.
Napoleon tenderly embraced the Empress Marie Louise.
Empress Marie Louise regarded Napoleon as her husband.
Napoleon had left another wife in Paris.
Napoleon left Marie Louise grieved by the parting she seemed hardly able to bear.
Diplomatists still firmly believed in the possibility of peace and worked zealously to that end.
Emperor Napoleon wrote a letter to Alexander calling him Monsieur mon frère.
Emperor Napoleon sincerely assured Alexander that he did not want war and would always love and honor him.
Napoleon set off to join his army.
At every station Napoleon gave fresh orders to accelerate the movement of his troops from west to east.
Napoleon went in a traveling coach with six horses.
Napoleon was surrounded by pages, aides-de-camp, and an escort.
Napoleon traveled along the road to Posen, Thorn, Danzig, and Königsberg.
At each of these towns thousands of people met Napoleon with excitement and enthusiasm.
The army was moving from west to east.
Relays of six horses carried Napoleon in the same direction.
On the tenth of June Napoleon spent the night in apartments prepared for him on the estate of a Polish count in the Vilkavisski forest.
The next day Napoleon overtook the army.
Napoleon went in a carriage to the Niemen.
Napoleon changed into a Polish uniform.
Napoleon drove to the riverbank in order to select a place for the crossing.
Napoleon saw on the other side some Cossacks.
Napoleon saw on the other side the wide-spreading steppes.
In the midst of those steppes lay the holy city of Moscow.
Moscow was the capital of a realm such as the Scythia into which Alexander the Great had marched.
Napoleon unexpectedly ordered an advance contrary to strategic and diplomatic considerations.
The next day Napoleon's army began to cross the Niemen.
